pullRequest.body:
This defines the `quasispectrum` of an element `a : A` where `A` is a non-unital `R`-algebra. When `A` is unital and `R` is a semifield, then `quasispectrum R a = spectrum R a âˆª {0}`. The definition proceeds via *quasiregular* elements, which are also defined herein. The quasispectrum will serve as the domain of the continuous functions appearing in the continuous functional calculus for non-unital algebras.

---

```suggestion
is because of this isomorphism, and the associated ties with multiplicative invertibility, that we
choose a `Monoid` (as opposed to an `AddMonoid`) structure on `Quasiregular`.  In addition,
```

Does this weird multiplication have a name? I find it a bit disturbing that `Quasiregular R` isn't actually the type of quasiregular elements of `R`. I can't really think of a better name for the structure though.

This bothered me as well, but I also couldn't think of a better name. I thought about `Quasi` but that seemed *far* too generic. I can't find a name for this multiplication anywhere. The text from which I garnered some of this was "Exercises in classical ring theory" by T.Y. Lam, but the author doesn't name this operation. It also doesn't appear to have a name in the older work "Real banach algebras" by Lars Ingelstam. So :shrug:
Maybe something like `PreQuasiregular R`, or `ExtQuasiregular R`...?

```suggestion
with binary operation `fun x y â†¦ y + x + x * y` and identity `0`. Elements of `R` which are
invertible in this monoid satisfy the predicate `IsQuasiregular`. -/
```
I guess this docstring was meant to be completed at some point!
